L1_summary_of_paper: The paper develops a structural theory of interorganizational power that extends resource dependence by incorporating indirect (network-embedded) power, and tests how these power positions shape corporate acquisition strategies and firm performance. Key constructs are (i) direct disadvantage—the focal firm’s dependence on a partner net of the partner’s dependence on the firm; (ii) indirect disadvantage—the focal firm’s exposure to a significant partner’s leverage exercised via intermediaries; and (iii) two-step leverage—the focal firm’s ability to neutralize a powerful partner by acquiring a non-partner that has power over that partner. Using BEA input–output tables (1997, 2002, 2007) linked to Compustat segments and SDC M&A (1997–2007), the authors operationalize firm–industry power asymmetries and estimate effects on (a) the likelihood and (b) the expenditure of acquisitions of partners and non-partners, and (c) industry-adjusted ROA. They find that greater direct and indirect disadvantages both increase partner-acquisition likelihood and spending; the motivation to gain two-step leverage increases non-partner acquisitions; and a firm’s total indirect disadvantage to all partners depresses performance. Contributions: introduces an operationalizable indirect power construct; generalizes two-step leverage from coopting ties to acquisitions; and offers a network-structural route from dependence to strategy and performance.
M3_unit_of_analysis_element: Other: Indirect disadvantage (structural power via intermediaries)
A1_citation: Zhu, D. H., & Westphal, J. D. (2021). Structural power, corporate strategy, and performance. Strategic Management Journal, 42(3), 624–651. https://doi.org/10.1002/smj.3239.
A5_replicability: Other: Mixed (public BEA IO tables; proprietary Compustat/SDC; no public code)
D2_identification: Other: Logistic panel with two-way clustered SEs; Heckman selection for expenditure; FE/GLS for ROA
D2_key_assumptions_addressed: Temporal ordering (predictors at t; outcomes over t..t+4)
Selection into positive expenditure addressed via Heckman first-stage exclusions
Extensive controls for dependence structure and firm/industry characteristics
D5_data_sources: U.S. BEA Input–Output tables (6-digit IO accounts; 1997, 2002, 2007)
U.S. Census concentration ratios / Compustat segment data
F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Observational design; heavy reliance on IO-based dyadic intensities and concentration ratios; construction of ‘significant partner’ threshold (0.01) could affect classification though authors show robustness; potential omitted variables in acquisition decisions despite extensive controls.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Map direct/indirect disadvantage to directional dependence asymmetry at firm–industry ties; total indirect disadvantage aggregates triadic paths across all partners to a firm-level exposure metric.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: P1: Greater direct disadvantage to a significant partner increases the likelihood and size of acquisitions of that partner.
P2: Greater indirect disadvantage to a significant partner independently increases the likelihood and size of acquisitions of that partner.
P3: The product of a focal firm’s direct disadvantage to a partner and the partner’s disadvantage to a non-partner predicts acquisitions of that non-partner (two-step leverage).
I1_mechanism_statements: Indirect disadvantage allows a significant partner to restrict the focal firm’s access to intermediary-controlled resources, extracting better exchange terms.
Acquiring a partner with an indirect advantage both removes indirect disadvantage and inherits the partner’s direct advantages over intermediaries.
Acquiring a non-partner that dominates a powerful partner yields two-step leverage, neutralizing direct disadvantage when direct acquisition is infeasible.
I3_theoretical_propositions: H1/H2: Direct and indirect disadvantages → higher likelihood and greater expenditure on acquiring exchange partners.
H3: Motivation to gain two-step leverage → higher likelihood and greater expenditure on acquiring non-partners.
H4: Total indirect disadvantage (aggregated over all partners) → lower industry-adjusted ROA.
J1_main_findings_summary: Both direct and indirect disadvantages significantly increase the likelihood of acquiring partners; marginal effects at means ≈ +10.1% and +56.0% respectively off a 2.2% base rate.
Direct and indirect disadvantages also increase acquisition expenditure on partners; +1 SD increases expenditure by ≈2% and ≈8%, respectively (Heckman second stage).
Motivation to gain two-step leverage significantly raises the likelihood of acquiring non-partners; marginal effect ≈ +5.9% off a 0.13% base rate.
Total indirect disadvantage to all partners is negatively associated with firm performance (industry-adjusted ROA) in FE and GLS models.
K1_contribution_summary: The study reframes power from a purely dyadic dependence to a structural property of a firm’s position in an exchange network, introduces measurable ‘indirect disadvantage,’ and shows that firms use acquisitions—of both partners and influential non-partners—to manage dependence. It further links a firm’s aggregate indirect exposure to lower profitability, positioning structural power as a pathway from network position to corporate strategy and performance.
